title: How to remember what cathode and anode are clearly - Quora

response.answer_text: Every electrochemical cell has a cathode and an anode. each electrochemical cell has an oxidation and a reduction happening (while the circuit is closed and electricity is running). Vowels together Anode Oxidation Consonants together: Cathode Reduction. When deciding on the direction of electron flow, go alphabetically. Electrons always flow (through the external circuit) from A to C; Anode to Cathode. at the anode, is oxidation, where the chemicals lose electrons and at the cathode is the reduction where the chemicals gain electrons. Remember LEO the lion goes GER. LEO Lose Electrons OxidationGER Gain Electrons Reduction.The charge on the electrode could be either positive or negative, depending on whether the cell is driving the electricity or vice versa. The negative charge will build up wherever the resistance that blocks the electricity is. In the galvanic cell, where spontaneous chemistry is driving electrons through the external circuit (like a AA battery in a flashlight) the resistance is in the circuit so the electrons pile up on the anode. The anode is negative and the cathode is positive because the chemistry is stripping electrons off it faster than they can get replaced through the external circuit. In an electrolytic cell, where an external source of energy is driving a non-spontaneous chemistry, the resistance is in the cell. So the electrons pile up on the cathode (it is negative) and they are stripped off the anode (it is positive). Finally, in the solution itself, anions go to the anode and cations go to the cathode. Some people wrote (incorrectly) that the ions are attracted to the oppositely charged electrode. It is NOT because of the charge of the electrodes that these ions move one way or the other. They move by random motion. In the case of the electrolytic cell (the anode is positive) where the chemistry is not spontaneous then yes, the anode happens to be positive and that would attract the anions but it is NOT the case in the galvanic cell, where the anions go to the anode even though it is negatively charge. They move by random motion where they then deposit their excess negative charge, making it negative.

Already many good answers, but I would like to add this one to show how electrophysiology makes it more confusing. Compare a battery with a stimulator - a device used to stimulate excitable tissues such as nerves or muscles. Both have an anode and a cathode. -----------------BATTERY A battery is a charge-separating device.  It stores electric energy by separating cations (positively-charged ions) and anions (negatively-charged ions).  One terminal of the battery contains an excess of cations: this is the positive terminal (cathode).  The other terminal contains an excess of anions: this is the negative terminal (anode).    Image source:  Rechargeable battery diagram convention - Storage4  In a discharging battery, wherein energy is being discharged by the battery to the circuit (LEFT IMAGE), the cathode is the positive terminal and the anode is the negative terminal. We say that conventional (positive) current flows from the cathode to the anode. In reality, electronic (negative) current flows from the anode to the cathode. In a charging battery, wherein energy from the circuit is charging the battery (RIGHT IMAGE), the reverse is true: positive current flows from anode to cathode and electronic current flows from cathode to anode.  -----------------STIMULATOR   Image source: Foundations of Electrical Stimulation  Unlike the battery, the stimulator anode is the positive pole since it discharges cations (not anions) into the body part being stimulated (usually extracellular fluid). The anodal current flows from the anode towards the tissue and back to the cathode (see pic). When applied to the surface of an excitable tissue (nerve/muscle), anodal current will increase the concentration of cations in the extracellular space. This will result in hyperpolarization of the cell membrane.  The stimulator cathode is the negative pole: it discharges anions (not cations) into the body part being stimulated (usually extracellular fluid). The cathodal current flows from the cathode towards the tissue and back to the anode. When applied to the surface of an excitable tissue (nerve/muscle), cathodal current will increase the concentration of anions in the extracellular space. This will result in depolarization of the cell membrane which, if sufficient in magnitude, will result in an action potential (nerve impulse or muscle activation).----------------- Tl;dr: The meaning of anode and cathode may vary depending on application and circuit behavior. As suggested by Robert Kaspar (see answer to Why do we define cathode (and anode) differently in galvanic cell and electrolytic cell?), confusion can be avoided if... [We] think of "anode" and "cathode" as roles rather than as permanent objects.  These roles indicate which way electrons are flowing.  For example, in a rechargeable battery, the same electrode that consumes electrons during electrolytic charging is the one that releases them during galvanic discharging.  The role changes even though the object stays the same. For devices that can behave both galvanically and electrolytically, just call the electrodes "positive" and "negative".

All you have to do is know the history of television. For the first 50 years or so all TVs used a picture tube rather than the plasma and LCD panels that have replaced them. These were called Cathode Ray Tubes (CRTs) as before J.J. Thompson discovered the electron in 1897 the emissions from vacuum tubes were thought to be Rays not particles. It should be clear that it is a lot easier to shoot electrons than protons so it makes sense that a Cathode RayTube shoots electrons. So a cathode sends out negative charges and attracts positive.    It may seem like this is a very inefficient way to remember what a cathode is. But I think you'll find it is a great technique. You know, for the past 43 years I have never had a problem remembering the square root of 3 or the year of Washington's birth. I didn't know either, but as soon as my high school math teacher told me to associate Washington's birth year, 1732, with the square root of three, 1.732 they have remained stuck in my mind.

A lot of the above answers (including the "best" answer) are WRONG. There is, understandably, a lot of confusion on this topic. The cathode or anode are not defined in GENERAL b y their respective charge, because they can have EITHER positive or negative charge depending on the situation. In general, the anode is the electrode that positive current flows INTO from the outside, and the cathode is the electrode that it flows FROM (to the outside). Electrons, of course, flow the opposite way.  In electrochemistry, the anode is where oxidation occurs and cathode is where reduction occurs ("an ox red cat"). Also, the anode always attracts negative anions and the cathode attracts positive cations. This happens REGARDLESS of the respective charges on the electrodes themselves (which depend on whether it's an electrochemical or electrolytic cell), as it is determined by the dominant charge of the ENVIRONMENT of the electrode, which is always negative in the case of the cathode (due to the reduction occurring there) and positive at the anode (due to the oxidation occurring there).  Hope It will be helpful .

I would look up the etymology of Cathode and Anode. You’ll find the following: Greek roots\words (English pronunciations): Cata: “down” (used in reference to an object) Ana: “up” (used in reference to an object) Hodos: “way/road” Ion: “to go” Cation= Cata + Ion Cathode = Cata + Hodos Anode = Ana + Hodos etc etc… We have to figure out what the ‘object’ is. This can be done by looking at what Cation could mean from the above roots. Perhaps it means “to go down” (in reference to an object). Since Cations (in Chem at least) are denoted with a superscript +[number of removed electrons], it would be implied that the object decreasing would be the reduction number i.e. the number of electrons. So the object must be electrons\elementary charge associated. This would imply that the current flows from cathode to anode, which in Chem is wrong for some reason, but from the etymology standpoint, is correct. I usually just apply the above reasoning to problems requiring it, then flip the anode/cathode designations to appease the ambiguous chem gods. I use this method to determine the designation because I cannot for the life of me remember the mnemonics that fail to answer the\a ‘why’ behind its reasoning. This way when I get a little rusty on my stuff I can resort to ‘elementary’ reasoning and not have to fumble trying to remember some (subjectively) asinine mnemonic.

Hi. I was wondering the same today and discovered the following over Wikipedia: Definitions of Anode and cathode depend on charge and discharge: Michael Faraday defined the cathode of a cell as the electrode to which cations (positively charged ions, like silver ions Ag+) flow within the cell, to be reduced by reacting with electrons (negatively charged) from that electrode. Likewise he defined the anode as the electrode to which anions (negatively charged ions, like chloride ions Cl−) flow within the cell, to be oxidized by depositing electrons on the electrode. To an external wire connected to the electrodes of a Galvanic cell (or battery), forming an electric circuit, the cathode is positive and the anode is negative. Thus positive electric current flows from the cathode to the anode through the external circuit in the case of a Galvanic cell. Consider two voltaic cells of unequal voltage. Mark the positive and negative electrodes of each one as P and N, respectively. Place them in a circuit with P near P and N near N, so the cells will tend to drive current in opposite directions. The cell with the larger voltage is discharged, making it a galvanic cell, so P is the cathode and N is the anode as described above. But, the cell with the smaller voltage charges, making it an electrolytic cell. In the electrolytic cell, negative ions are driven towards P and positive ions towards N. Thus, the P electrode of the electrolytic cell meets the definition of anode while the electrolytic cell is being charged. Similarly, the N electrode of the electrolytic cell is the cathode while the electrolytic cell is being charged. In Simple words: Electrolytic cells convert electrical energy into chemical energy.Conventional current flows into the (+) terminal of the cell and comes out from (-) terminal. Electrons flow in reverse direction.Hence, the (+) electrode is called anode & the (-) electrode is called cathode.Galvanic cells convert chemical energy into electrical energy.Conventional current flows from the (+) terminal of the cell and goes into (-) terminal. Electrons flow in reverse direction.Hence, (+) electrode is called cathode and (-) electrode is called anode.The root cause of your confusion is: Non-rechargeable batteries are galvanic cells, but rechargeable batteries behave like electrolytic cell while charging & galvanic cells while discharging. In the end, to avoid any confusion, follow Robert Kaspar’s suggestion of denoting the terminals by (+) and (-) as suggested in Robert Kaspar's answer to Why do we define cathode (and anode) differently in a galvanic cell and an electrolytic cell?. Source: Electrolytic cell - Wikipedia

In: Electrolytic cell Anode: positive Cathode: negative Electrochemical cell Anode: negativeCathode: positive HOW TO REMEMBER ? Electrolytic cell : Anion goes to Anode, Cation goes to cathode. Since -ve goes to +ve and +ve goes to -ve, Anode is positive and cathode is negative. Electrochemical cell : Opposite.

This can be pretty confusing at times, happened to me as well. Its because the anodes and cathodes change signs under different conditions. In a discharging battery (Galvanic cell), the anode is the negative terminal, and cathode is positive. In a recharging battery (Electrolytic cell), the opposite happens, anode is positive and cathode is negative. Here, the mnemonic PRANC (rhymes with prank) can be used, P- Positive. R-Recharging, A-Anode, N-Negative, C-Cathode. As the mnemonic for recharging a battery is now available, so we can just easily remember that the opposite will happen if battery is discharging.

Hey dude!! I too have been through this question but after finer researches I gathered the substantial and easiest way to remember. Universal definition of cathode- electrode where reduction occurs. Universal definition of anode- electrode where oxidation occurs. You know where the confusion arises?? We get baffled when we learn electrochemical and electrolytic cell simultaneously. Taking into consideration the cathode and anode of both the cells, their nature is opposite. What acts as cathode in electrolytic cell, it acts as anode in in electrochemical cell and vice versa. Thereby confusing pupil. But when you introspect the electrodes with the above universal definitions you will get the answer. Hope it helps. Thanks ❣️

In a vacuum tube and similar devices, the cathode has a negative charge and the anode is positive. In electrochemical cells, the criteria are different: not the sign of the charge, but the nature of the chemical reaction (properly speaking, half-reaction) that takes place at the electrode. The cathode is the electrode at which reduction takes place, and the anode is the one at which oxidation takes place. In a galvanic cell, i.e., a “battery”, in which a spontaneous chemical reaction produces electrical current, that means the anode will be the negative electrode and the cathode will be positive. In an electrolytic cell, in which an electrical potential is applied to force a non-spontaneous reaction to occur, the anode will positive and the cathode will be negative. Either way, electrons flow from the anode to the cathode, but the difference is whether they do so spontaneously or are forced to flow.
Cations(+) to cathode, Anions(-) to anode.So cathode is the +ve terminal in a battery and the -ve terminal in an electrolytic cell. Opposite for anode.

Electrons enter the device through the cathode and leave through the anode. This is true for electron tubes ("valves" in British English), semiconductor diodes, electrolytic cells, cathodic protection systems and batteries. The anode in an electron tube is often called the plate, or in the case of a microwave klystron, the collector (actually one of two anodes). Whether the anode is positive or negative with respect to the cathode depends on the device, in particular whether it produces or dissipates power. In a battery, the anode is negative with respect to the cathode. In a vacuum tube, the anode is positive. Rechargeable batteries are a special case since current can flow in either direction, and technically the anode and cathode switch places. Most literature seems to assume the battery is being discharged, i.e., the negative plate is the anode just as in a one-use battery.

Here anode is positive and cathode is negative. Electrochemical cell which converts chemical energy to electrical energy. Here anode is negative and cathode ispositiv

ANion can be remembered as A Negative ion. And you may be knowing that anions move towards anode. An negatively charged particle move to positively charged electode. So anode is positively charged. this holds good for eletolytic cell. for galvanic cell it becomes reversed.

Cathodes are the electrodes where reduction reaction takes place and anodes are the electrodes where oxidation reaction takes place.if you are doing electrolysis in voltaic cell then the cathodes are negatively charged and anodes are positively charged.but if are generating electricity by doing some chemical reaction in the galvanic cell then the cathodes are positively charged and anodes are negatively charged…

The reduction potentials help in determining the electrodes. On anode, oxidation occurs and on cathode, the reduction occurs. You don't have to remember cathode or anode. Watch the following video, and you will be able to tell easily which one is cathode and which one is anode from the question.

It is really exhausting to learn which is positive and which is negative. This confusion of ours often leads to mistakes in the exam. But I think if we use short tricks and methods like the one I am going to tell you, then we can memorise any confusing term in just a few minutes and would never forget it. SO HERE IT IS!!!! So the short cut is “PANIC”. we all use this word frequently but today we would use it to clear our confusion. P- POSITIVE A-ANODE N-NEGATIVE I-IS C-CATHODE Similarly you can remember ANION as the opposite of ANODE and CATION as the opposite of CATHODE.

Formal current enters a device at the anode. This means electrons flow out at the anode. Formal charge leaves a device at the cathode which means electrons flow in at the cathode. For electrochemical cells, galvanic or otherwise, reduction occurs at the cathode and oxidation at the anode. The terms cathode and anode describe the function of the electrode, not their charge.

Cathode: site of reduction Anode : site of oxidation In Galvanic Cell: Zn-Cu zinc will oxidized to Zn+2 ion and copper ion reduced to copper. In electrolytic cell: Copper strip attached to negative terminal will act as cathode and copper ions Will be reduced to copper, increasing its size. Copper strip attached to positive terminal will act as anode and release copper ion and electrons, reducing its size.

Cathode has negative charge. Anode has positive charge. If in aqueous solution the cations move towards Cathode coz it has negative charge (opposite charge attraction) and in aqueous solution the anions move towards Anode which is positively charged. Reduction occurs at Cathode Oxidation at Anode.

Hi, Cathode is the positive electrode in Galvanic cells where reduction occurs (REDCAT). Anode is where Oxidation takes place (ANOX) and is the negative electrode in a Galvanic cell. The polarities change for Electrolytic cells but the reduction and oxidation rules hold true. Check this link out, it explains it quickly on youtube (Galvanic and Electrolytic Cells)
Anode; electrode at which oxidation(loss of electron by electrolyte) takes placeCathode ; electrode at which reduction(gain of electron by electrolyte) takes place
In the case of diodes, it’s easy:

Cathode- negatively charged electrode. Anode-positively charged electrode. Cations-positively charged ions. Anions-negatively charged ions. Cathode attracts cations whereas anions-negatively attract anion.

neither have “charge”. the anode is one side of the P-N junction that defines the diode. normally, the anode is associated as positive because that is when the diode will conduct. the cathode is normally associated with the negative. the electron charge that flows when in the “on” direction, (anode positive) will flow from anode to cathode.
